natural problem: A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth.
natural solution: The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.

We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = 1/2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "y = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "y = 1"
shows  "area = 8.45"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = 1/2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "y = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "y = 1"
shows  "area = 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given three lines, y = 1/2x + 3, y = -2x + 6, and y = 1, the area enclosed by these lines is 8.45 square units.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. A x = 1 / 2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. B x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. C x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 8.45"
shows  "area = (\<bar>integral {x. A x \<le> C x \<and> B x \<ge> C x} (\<lambda>x. A x - B x)\<bar> + \<bar>integral {x. B x \<le> C x} (\<lambda>x. B x - C x)\<bar>)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. A x = 1 / 2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. B x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. C x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 8.45"
shows  "area = (\<bar>integral {x. A x \<le> C x \<and> B x \<ge> C x} (\<lambda>x. A x - B x)\<bar> + \<bar>integral {x. B x \<le> C x} (\<lambda>x. B x - C x)\<bar>)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the area of the region enclosed by the graphs of the following functions: $A(x) = \frac{1}{2}x + 3, B(x) = -2x + 6$, and $C(x) = 1$. The final answer is 8.45 square units.

theorem
fixes area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. y = (1 / 2) * x + 3 \<or> y = (-2) * x + 6 \<or> y = 1"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real * real"
and l1 l2 l3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. l1 x = 0.5 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. l2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. l3 x = 1"
and h3 : "A = (x1, l1 x1) \<and> B = (x2, l1 x2) \<and> C = (x3, l1 x3)"
and h4 : "A = (x4, l2 x4) \<and> B = (x5, l2 x5) \<and> C = (x6, l2 x6)"
and h5 : "A = (x7, l3 x7) \<and> B = (x8, l3 x8) \<and> C = (x9, l3 x9)"
shows  "area_triangle A B C = 8.45"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real * real"
and l1 l2 l3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. l1 x = 0.5 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. l2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. l3 x = 1"
and h3 : "A = (x1, l1 x1) \<and> B = (x2, l1 x2) \<and> C = (x3, l1 x3)"
and h4 : "A = (x4, l2 x4) \<and> B = (x5, l2 x5) \<and> C = (x6, l2 x6)"
and h5 : "A = (x7, l3 x7) \<and> B = (x8, l3 x8) \<and> C = (x9, l3 x9)"
shows  "area_triangle A B C = 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given three lines $l_1(x) = 0.5x + 3$, $l_2(x) = -2x + 6$, and $l_3(x) = 1$, find the area of the triangle formed by the intersection points A, B, and C of these lines, where A is the intersection point of lines $l_1$ and $l_2$, B is the intersection point of lines $l_1$ and $l_3$, and C is the intersection point of lines $l_2$ and $l_3$. The final answer is 8.45.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area :: real and y1 y2 y3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = 1/2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 1/2 * (abs (intersect y1 y2 - intersect y1 y3) * abs (intersect y2 y3 - intersect y1 y3))"
shows  "area = 8.45"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45

The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = 1/2 * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 1/2 * (abs (intersect y1 y2 - intersect y1 y3) * abs (intersect y2 y3 - intersect y1 y3))"
shows  "area = 8.45"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the area of a triangle formed by the intersection points of three lines: $y_1 = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$, $y_2 = -2x + 6$, and $y_3 = 1$. The final answer is 8.45.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. (y = (1/2) * x + 3) \<or> (y = -2 * x + 6) \<or> (y = 1) \<longrightarrow> enclosed_area x y"
and h1 : "area = (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. \<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator (enclosed_area x y) x y)"
shows  "area = 8.45"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45

 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. (y = (1/2) * x + 3) \<or> (y = -2 * x + 6) \<or> (y = 1) \<longrightarrow> enclosed_area x y"
and h1 : "area = (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. \<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator (enclosed_area x y) x y)"
shows  "area = 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: real and lines :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = (1/2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = 1"
and h3 : "A = (\<lambda>x y. (1/2) * base * height) (intercept_x h0 h1) (intercept_y h0 h1)"
shows  "A \<approx> 8.45"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: real and lines :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = (1/2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>x y. lines x y = 1"
and h3 : "A = (\<lambda>x y. (1/2) * base * height) (intercept_x h0 h1) (intercept_y h0 h1)"
shows  "A \<approx> 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the area of a triangle with vertices at the intersections of the lines $y = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$, and $y = 1$. The area of the triangle is approximately 8.45.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area_triangle :: real
assumes h0 : "area_triangle = (1 / 2) * abs (intersect_x y1 y2 - intersect_x y1 y3) * abs (y2 - y3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = (1 / 2) * x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> y1 y2. intersect_x y1 y2 = (y1 - y2) / (slope y1 - slope y2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> y. slope y = (y x1 - y x0) / (x1 - x0)"
shows  "area_triangle = 8.45"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes area_triangle :: real
assumes h0 : "area_triangle = (1 / 2) * abs (intersect_x y1 y2 - intersect_x y1 y3) * abs (y2 - y3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = (1 / 2) * x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> y1 y2. intersect_x y1 y2 = (y1 - y2) / (slope y1 - slope y2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> y. slope y = (y x1 - y x0) / (x1 - x0)"
shows  "area_triangle = 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given three lines $y_1 = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$, $y_2 = -2x + 6$, and $y_3 = 1$, find the area of the triangle formed by their intersection points. The final answer is 8.45.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. A x = (1/2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. B x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. C x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 8.45"
shows  "area = (\<triangle> A B C)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45

 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. A x = (1/2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. B x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. C x = 1"
and h3 : "area = 8.45"
shows  "area = (\<triangle> A B C)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the area of a triangle formed by the intersection of three lines: $A(x) = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$, $B(x) = -2x + 6$, and $C(x) = 1$. The area of the triangle is 8.45.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes y1 y2 y3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = (1 / 2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h3 : "closed_segment y1 y2"
and h4 : "closed_segment y2 y3"
and h5 : "closed_segment y3 y1"
and h6 : "area {x. y1 x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> y2 x \<and> y3 x \<le> y} = A"
shows  "A = 8.45"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular region is enclosed by the lines with equations $y = \frac{1}{2} x + 3$, $y = -2x + 6$ and $y = 1$. What is the area of the triangular region? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth. The final Answer is 8.45
 ### Proof
 The vertices of the triangle are the points where two of the lines intersect. The line  $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=1\Rightarrow x=-4.$$ The line $y=-2x+6$ intersects $y=1$ when  $$-2x+6=1\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2}.$$  The line $y=\frac{1}{2}x+3$ intersects $y=-2x+6$ when  $$\frac{1}{2}x+3=-2x+6\Rightarrow x=\frac{6}{5}.$$ and  $$y=-2\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)+6=\frac{18}{5}$$
 Thus the vertices of the triangle are $(-4,1)$, $\left(\frac{5}{2},1\right)$, and $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$.
 We can let the base of the triangle lie along the line $y=1$. It will have length  $$4+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{13}{2}.$$  The altitude from $\left(\frac{6}{5},\frac{18}{5}\right)$ to this line will have length  $$\frac{18}{5}-1=\frac{13}{5}.$$ Thus the area of the triangle is $$\frac{1}{2}*\frac{13}{2}*\frac{13}{5}=\frac{169}{20}=\boxed{8.45}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes y1 y2 y3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y1 x = (1 / 2) * x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y2 x = -2 * x + 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. y3 x = 1"
and h3 : "closed_segment y1 y2"
and h4 : "closed_segment y2 y3"
and h5 : "closed_segment y3 y1"
and h6 : "area {x. y1 x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> y2 x \<and> y3 x \<le> y} = A"
shows  "A = 8.45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider three linear functions defined by $y1(x) = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$, $y2(x) = -2x + 6$, and $y3(x) = 1$. These functions form a closed polygon in the x-y plane. Find the area (A) of this polygon. The final answer is $A = 8.45$ square units.
